Award.AwardTitle: Poromechanics Beyond the Second Law of Thermodynamics

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The entire field of continuum mechanics has been developed subject to the axiom of the second law of thermodynamics. This axiom implies a non-negative rate of irreversible entropy production. Yet, the results of contemporary physics have shown that this law does not hold at very small spatial and/or temporal scales. The fluctuation theorem instead describes entropy as a stochastic quantity that is exponentially more likely to be positive than negative and, upon ensemble averaging, leads to the conventional second law inequality. This theorem has already replaced the second law in considerations of the rheological and thermal responses of liquids. Consequently, the continuum models for fluid filled porous media must be reformulated. The research outcomes would be significant both for the fundamental understanding of geological, biological and man-made materials. In particular, mechanistic description of the material responses will be modified according to the microstructure and its characteristic length scales. As a result, this research will provide new insight into the mechanics of highly complex media such as gels, fluid-saturated rock systems, cardiovascular and pulmonary tissues. The PI plans to offer short courses related to the mechanics of random and fractal materials and structures, and will expand the delivery of a high-school-level short course on fractals. Selected images and animations obtained through the research will be integrated into outreach programs to enrich the K-12 educational system.

Research supported under this award seeks to define a paradigm shift in continuum mechanics and, especially, poromechanics. The research aims to answer the question how the consideration of the fluctuation theorem may alter our understanding of the continuum mechanics of porous media. A stochastic thermomechanics framework with internal variables considering the fluctuation theorem in place of the second law axiom will be formulated. The admission of random scatter in nanoscale systems, with possible violations of the Clausius-Duhem inequality, will lead to a modification of Darcy's law, of the poromechanical constitutive relations and of the heat conduction relations. The new formulation would explicitly account for scale dependence. The effective permeability and heat conduction moduli are expected to turn out to be higher than as dictated by classical continuum theories. Next, homogenized constitutive descriptions will be established based on a micropolar theory for the use in random, and possibly fractal, fluid-saturated media. New forms of field and differential equations will be derived and employed to derive solutions of relevant initial-boundary value problems, thereby modifying the conventional solutions of problems of continuum poromechanics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Whereas the entire field of continuum mechanics/physics has been developed subject to the axiom of Second Law of thermodynamics (requiring a non-negative rate of irreversible entropy production), the results of contemporary physics have shown that this law does not hold on very small spatial and/or temporal scales. With the fluctuation theorem replacing the Second Law in rheological and thermal responses of atomic/molecular fluids/materials, the continuum models have been reformulated in this project. Overall, these models set the stage for: (i) studies of spontaneous nanoscale violations of the Second Law of thermodynamics in fluid-saturated porous materials as modeled by the fluctuation theorem of statistical mechanics; (ii) scaling behaviors in such materials; and (iii) permeability and poromechanics of nano-structured materials. New forms of field/governing equations have been derived by generalizing the framework of thermomechanics with internal variables (TIV), whereby the dissipation function (and possibly the free energy) becomes a stochastic functional(s), with its coefficients being tensor random fields over the material domain. This modifies the treatments of conventional (based on the Second Law axiom) deterministic initial-boundary value problems of continuum poromechanics and continuum physics.

In particular, extensive work has been carried out on Couette flows of atomic/molecular fluids and their continuum representations. Non-equilibrium molecular dynamics simulations, the Boltzmann equation, and continuum thermomechanics have been combined to investigate and characterize the shear-thinning behavior of fluids interacting via the Lennard-Jones (LJ) potential. Next, we carried out a study of: autocorrelations and spectral densities of the shear stress, the bispectral density of the shear stress as a measure of departure from a Gaussian model, determination of conditions under which the shear-stress acts as a narrow-band or wide-band random process, and the role of critical strain rate at which an ordering transition occurs in the fluid causing shear thinning and affecting its stability. Using this framework, we have then studied a transition from laminar to turbulent flows at subcritical Reynolds numbers. Via the Poincaré inequality, we arrived at a new stability criterion by providing a lower bound on the exponential decay of perturbations, and obtained a fluid dependent estimate for the critical Reynolds number, overall giving a framework by which one may generalize classical fluid mechanics to the nano/micro-scale.

In order to provide a more complete framework, extensive supporting research was done on random multiscale composites, including: wave propagation in random fractal media (with an application to traumatic brain injury), avalanches and damage in amorphous materials, homogenization by classical or micropolar continua of random and/or fractal media, scaling in random heterogeneous media, fractional calculus for viscoelasticity of fractal media, and tensor-valued random fields (TRFs).

Motivated by the need to develop a stochastic TIV theory, a coverage of the TRFs of ranks 1 through 4 from a unified perspective has been given in a book form. The scope of presentation goes under a label “wide-sense homogeneous and isotropic, second order TRFs” with the primary focus being on the correlation tensors characterizing such fields. Thus, the monograph gives a complete and explicit representation of most general correlation functions of TRFs of ranks 1, 2, 3, and 4.  In other words, any homogeneous and isotropic TRF has the correlation structure described by the formulas in this book. On the physical applications’ side, two types of TRFs are of particular concern: those of dependent fields and those of constitutive properties. The first type must satisfy laws of physics which in continuum theories are expressed by the balance equations, e.g. linear momentum. In consequence, the correlation functions are found to be subject to certain restrictions. The second type of TRFs must satisfy the positive definiteness and specific symmetry conditions as dictated by the particular symmetry class. This work has multifarious applications of TRFs in continuum mechanics/physics including, besides TIV of fluids and solids, the classical and micropolar continua, the founding of stochastic partial differential equations on tensor (rather than, as conventionally done, scalar) random fields, and even planetary rings of fractal structure.

Overall, this project has the potential for a significant impact on the applicability of continuum mechanics/physics to studies of nanoscale-controlled responses of natural (geological, biological...) and man-made materials. As a result, the highly complex (even possibly fractal) media (e.g., polymer clusters, gels, fluid-saturated rock systems, cardiovascular and pulmonary systems) will soon be open to studies conventionally reserved for smooth materials, including spontaneous nanoscale violations of the Second Law of thermodynamics.
